Age of Information in Federated Learning over Wireless Networks

Kaidi Wang, , Yi Ma, , Mahdi Boloursaz Mashhadi, , Chuan Heng Foh, , Rahim Tafazolli, , and Zhi Ding K. Wang, Y. Ma, M. Boloursaz Mashhadi, C. Foh, and R. Tafazolli are with 5GIC & 6GIC, Institute for Communication Systems (ICS), University of Surrey, Guildford, United Kingdom (email: kaidi.wang@ieee.org; y.ma@surrey.ac.uk; m.boloursazmashhadi@surrey.ac.uk; c.foh@surrey.ac.uk; r.tafazolli@surrey.ac.uk).Z. Ding is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616 USA (email: zding@ucdavis.edu).
Abstract

In this paper, federated learning (FL) over wireless networks is investigated. In each communication round, a subset of devices is selected to participate in the aggregation with limited time and energy. In order to minimize the convergence time, global loss and latency are jointly considered in a Stackelberg game based framework. Specifically, age of information (AoI) based device selection is considered at leader-level as a global loss minimization problem, while sub-channel assignment, computational resource allocation, and power allocation are considered at follower-level as a latency minimization problem. By dividing the follower-level problem into two sub-problems, the best response of the follower is obtained by a monotonic optimization based resource allocation algorithm and a matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm. By deriving the upper bound of convergence rate, the leader-level problem is reformulated, and then a list based device selection algorithm is proposed to achieve Stackelberg equilibrium. Simulation results indicate that the proposed device selection scheme outperforms other schemes in terms of the global loss, and the developed algorithms can significantly decrease the time consumption of computation and communication.

Index Terms:
Age of information, device selection, federated learning (FL), resource allocation, sub-channel assignment

I Introduction

With the rapid development of mobile devices and applications, the amount of data is exploded in the fifth-generation (5G) era, which leads to the great progress in machine learning (ML) [1]. In conventional centralized ML, a central server is equipped at the access point (AP) to collect all raw data for model training. However, due to the limited wireless resources and potential privacy issues, centralized ML is impractical for some scenarios [2]. In this context, federated learning (FL) has been proposed as a distributed ML algorithm to train neural networks while keeping the data locally [3]. Specifically, in FL, a global model is shared among multiple devices, and each device trains the received global model based on the local data and produces a local model [4]. After that, all local models are transmitted to the server via wireless communication networks to generate the updated global model [5]. Since the raw data does not leave the device, and the size of the model is much smaller than the data, privacy-sensitive issues can be avoided and less communication resources are consumed.

I-A Related Works

Due to the characteristics of FL, the related design and optimization in existing wireless communication architectures have attracted much attention. The convergence time, which is jointly determined by the number of communication rounds and the time consumption per round, is regarded as an important metric for evaluating the performance of FL [6].

By confirming the relationship between global loss and convergence bound, some works focused on the global loss minimization problem in order to increase the convergence rate, or reduce the number of required communication rounds [7, 8, 9, 10, 11]. Specifically, in [7], the authors have designed a FL algorithm with multiple local training. The impact of local and global update rounds on the convergence bound was analyzed, and the approximate solution of the global loss minimization problem was obtained. In [8], the packet error rate was introduced to indicate whether the parameter transmission was successful or not, and then user selection, resource block allocation, and power allocation were jointly studied under delay and energy constraints. FL was also considered in a massive multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) scenario with energy harvesting, where user scheduling and power allocation were included in the global loss minimization problem [9]. Moreover, this work was extended to a multi-cell system, and user association between users and base stations (BSs) was considered. The model pruning scheme was adopted in [10], where the unimportant weights can be set to zero in order to reduce the model size. In this paper, device selection, time slot allocation and pruning ratio were jointly optimized to maximize the convergence rate with a latency constraint. In [11], a global loss minimization problem was formulated with the total time consumption limitation, and then decoupled into a device scheduling problem and a bandwidth allocation problem. By analyzing the convergence bound of FL, the trade-off between the latency of each round and the number of required rounds was revealed.

As another factor in determining the convergence time, latency of FL, including computation time and communication time, was extensively researched in previous works [12, 13, 14, 15]. In [12], a realistic wireless network was designed for FL, where a limited number of users can be selected at each round for aggregation. By obtaining user selection and resource block allocation schemes, the convergence time of FL was minimized. By setting a local accuracy level at each device, the FL algorithm with multiple local update rounds was proposed in a cell-free massive MIMO scenario [13]. Moreover, in the formulated training time minimization problem, time consumption for downlink transmission, uplink transmission, and computation were comprehensively considered. A multi-task FL framework was studied in a multiaccess edge computing (MEC) scenario, where edge nodes were included to accomplish different learning tasks [14]. In order to minimize the latency of each communication round, the optimal matching between edge nodes and end devices was obtained. The authors in [15] have proposed a hybrid learning scheme which combined edge computing and FL. Particularly, part of data can be offloaded from devices to the server for training, and then the local models can be trained based on the remaining data. It was demonstrated that the proposed scheme has the ability to reduce the total time consumption.

I-B Motivation and Contribution

As forwarded mentioned, global loss minimization and latency minimization were extensively researched in existing works. However, most works have studied it individually. As pointed out in [11], there exists a trade-off between global loss and latency. That is, some devices with the great positive impact on global loss may have poor channel conditions or weak computational capacities, and hence, the latency of this communication round will be obviously increased. Normally, the latency can be reduced by increasing transmit power or central processing unit (CPU) frequency, which means consuming more energy [16]. Hence, there exists another trade-off in FL, i.e., the interaction between latency and energy consumption. Even though global loss and latency were jointly studied in [11], it is necessary to consider the practical energy budget in a latency minimization problem and the possible impact on the global loss. In this paper, based on Stackelberg game, the interaction between global loss minimization and latency minimization are investigated with limited energy and time. It is revealed that the negative effects caused by energy and time constraints can be reduced by optimizing the CPU frequency and transmit power. On the other hand, due to the fact that the number of devices participating in FL is usually much larger than the number of available sub-channels, device selection is commonly considered in the FL based wireless communication framework. The conventional device selection scheme depends on either wireless resources [8] or local models [10, 12]. In this paper, a novel age of information (AoI) based device selection scheme is proposed, which can improve the convergence rate without analyzing local models. The main contributions are listed as follows:

  • •

    A latency-sensitive FL scenario is considered, where multiple devices transmit parameters to the server with the limited number of sub-channels. By introducing AoI, a weighed device selection scheme is proposed. In order to jointly minimize global loss and latency, a Stackelberg game based problem is formulated, where global loss minimization and latency minimization are considered as leader-level and follower-level problems, respectively.

  • •

    The follower-level problem is divided into two sub-problems, including resource allocation and sub-channel assignment. Due to non-convexity and monotonicity, a monotonic optimization based solution is proposed for the resource allocation problem. Moreover, a matching based algorithm is developed to address the sub-channel assignment problem, where the properties of the proposed algorithm are analyzed.

  • •

    For solving the leader-level problem, the upper bound of the convergence rate is derived, and then the global loss minimization problem is reformulated as a weighted device selection problem. By ordering devices based on information age and data size, a list is established, and an algorithm is proposed to select devices by testing sub-channel assignment and resource allocation.

  • •

    The simulation results based on the Modified National Institute of Standards and Technology (MNIST) database is presented. It is indicated that the AoI based device selection algorithm can improve the performance of FL on both independent identically distributed (IID) and non-IID data. Moreover, the proposed solution of resource allocation can significantly reduce the latency of each communication round.

I-C Organization

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II and Section III, the system model and problem formulation are described, respectively. The solution of latency minimization problem is presented in Section IV, and the solution of global loss minimization problem is obtained in Section V. Section VI demonstrates the simulation results. The conclusions are summarized in Section VII.

II System Model

Consider an FL scenario where N𝑁N wireless devices collaboratively train a joint learning model. Each device is equipped with a single antenna and the FL process is orchestrated by a wireless server. The set of all devices is denoted by 𝒩={1,2,…,N}𝒩12…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\dots,N\}. Specifically, each device intends to train neural networks based on its local data and then transmit the parameters to the server for aggregation. The limited communication resources are considered in this paper. That is, there are K𝐾K available sub-channels, where K≤N𝐾𝑁K\leq N, and each sub-channel can be occupied by one device. The set of all sub-channels is denoted by 𝒦={1,2,…,K}𝒦12…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,2,\dots,K\}. Therefore, in any round t𝑡t, only a subset of devices can be selected for the global model aggregation. The procedure of the considered FL framework is presented as follows:

  1. 1.

    In any round t𝑡t, the server broadcasts the global model 𝒈(t)superscript𝒈𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)} to all devices.

  2. 2.

    Each selected device trains the received global model and generate a local model 𝒘n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{(t)}.

  3. 3.

    The selected devices transmit local models to the server through the assigned sub-channels.

  4. 4.

    The server aggregates the received models to generate an updated global model 𝒈(t+1)superscript𝒈𝑡1\boldsymbol{g}^{(t+1)}.

Starting from t=1𝑡1t=1, the above procedure will repeat until the FL converges.

II-A Computation Model

After receiving the global model, the selected devices need to train their respective local learning models by utilizing the equipped CPUs. For any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k, the computational time consumption is given by

Tk,ncp​(τk,n)=μ​βnτk,n​Cn,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cpsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛T_{k,n}^{\text{cp}}(\tau_{k,n})=\frac{\mu\beta_{n}}{\tau_{k,n}C_{n}}, (1)

where μ𝜇\mu is a coefficient to denote the required CPU cycles for training one sample, βnsubscript𝛽𝑛\beta_{n} is the number of samples at device n𝑛n, τk,nsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n} is a designed proportion of computational capacity, and Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} is the CPU frequency of device n𝑛n. It is worth mentioning that the computation phase is affected by the assigned sub-channel, though without explicit channel gain in (1). Specifically, for any device, the time consumption and energy consumption of transmission vary with different sub-channels, and hence, the computational resource allocation coefficient τ𝜏\tau should be dynamically adjusted according to allocated sub-channel gains. According to [17], the energy consumption for computation can be expressed as follows:

Ek,ncp​(τk,n)=κ0​μ​βn​(τk,n​Cn)2,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cpsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝜅0𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛2E_{k,n}^{\text{cp}}(\tau_{k,n})=\kappa_{0}\mu\beta_{n}(\tau_{k,n}C_{n})^{2}, (2)

where κ0subscript𝜅0\kappa_{0} is the power consumption coefficient per CPU cycle.

II-B Communication Model

At this phase, the local models are transmitted from the selected devices to the server. For any device n𝑛n, the achievable data rate at sub-channel k𝑘k is given by

Rk,n​(Pk,n)=B​log2⁡(1+Pk,n​|hk,n|2),subscript𝑅𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2R_{k,n}(P_{k,n})=B\log_{2}(1+P_{k,n}|h_{k,n}|^{2}), (3)

where B𝐵B is the bandwidth, Pk,nsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛P_{k,n} is the transmit power of device n𝑛n, and |hk,n|2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2|h_{k,n}|^{2} is the normalized channel gain. Particularly, |hk,n|2=|h~k,n|2​σ−2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑘𝑛2superscript𝜎2|h_{k,n}|^{2}=|\tilde{h}_{k,n}|^{2}\sigma^{-2}, where h~k,nsubscript~ℎ𝑘𝑛\tilde{h}_{k,n} is the complex-value Gaussian channel between device n𝑛n and the server via sub-channel k𝑘k, and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the variance of additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN). Based on the achievable data rate, the time consumption for communication can be presented as follows:

Tk,ncm​(Pk,n)=D​(𝒘n)Rk,n​(Pk,n),superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cmsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛𝐷subscript𝒘𝑛subscript𝑅𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛T_{k,n}^{\text{cm}}(P_{k,n})=\frac{D(\boldsymbol{w}_{n})}{R_{k,n}(P_{k,n})}, (4)

where D​(𝒘n)𝐷subscript𝒘𝑛D(\boldsymbol{w}_{n}) is the size of the local model at device n𝑛n. It is assumed that the data size of local models is the same for all devices, i.e., D​(𝒘)=D​(𝒘n),∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequence𝐷𝒘𝐷subscript𝒘𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩D(\boldsymbol{w})=D(\boldsymbol{w}_{n}),\forall n\in\mathcal{N}. The energy consumption for communication is given by

Ek,ncm​(Pk,n)=Pk,n​Tk,ncm​(Pk,n).superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cmsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cmsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛E_{k,n}^{\text{cm}}(P_{k,n})=P_{k,n}T_{k,n}^{\text{cm}}(P_{k,n}). (5)

II-C Device Selection

Since the number of sub-channels is less than or equal to the number of devices, a subset of devices, denoted by 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t}, is selected in round t𝑡t, i.e., 𝒩t⊆𝒩subscript𝒩𝑡𝒩\mathcal{N}_{t}\subseteq\mathcal{N} and |𝒩t|≤Ksubscript𝒩𝑡𝐾|\mathcal{N}_{t}|\leq K. The status of any device in round t𝑡t can be represented by a binary variable Sn(t)∈{0,1}superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡01S_{n}^{(t)}\in\{0,1\}, where Sn(t)=1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡1S_{n}^{(t)}=1 indicates device n𝑛n is selected to participate in the aggregation in round t𝑡t; Sn(t)=0superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡0S_{n}^{(t)}=0 otherwise. The set of all device selection indicators is denoted by 𝐒𝐒\mathbf{S}. Therefore, in any round, the set of selected devices 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t} and the set of device selection indicators 𝐒𝐒\mathbf{S} can be mutually inferred.

In order to improve the performance of FL, the status of devices is determined by data quality. It is revealed in [18, 19] that staleness of gradient update may negatively impact learning outcomes. Therefore, the server tends to select the devices with lager age of gradient update for aggregation. In particular, if a device has been skipped for several rounds, its gradient update is relatively informative, and the probability of the server selecting the device should increase. Conversely, if a device was selected in the previous round, the probability for its reselection should decrease. In order to evaluate the staleness, the concept of AoI is introduced [20, 21]. The information age of any device n𝑛n in round t𝑡t, denoted by An(t)superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡A_{n}^{(t)}, is a integer variable, defined as follows:

An(t)={An(t−1)+1,ifSn(t−1)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t−1)=0,1,ifSn(t−1)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t−1)=1,superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡casessuperscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡11ifsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡101ifsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡11A_{n}^{(t)}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}A_{n}^{(t-1)}+1,&\!\!\!\!\!\quad\text{if}\quad S_{n}^{(t-1)}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\psi_{k,n}^{(t-1)}=0,\\ 1,&\!\!\!\!\!\quad\text{if}\quad S_{n}^{(t-1)}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\psi_{k,n}^{(t-1)}=1,\end{array}\right. (6)

where ψk,n(t)∈{0,1}superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡01\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\in\{0,1\} is the sub-channel assignment indicator. Particularly, ψk,n(t)=1superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡1\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}=1 indicates device n𝑛n is assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k in round t𝑡t; ψk,n(t)=0superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡0\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}=0 otherwise. The above definition shows that the information age of any device in any round is determined by device selection and sub-channel assignment in the previous round. As shown in Fig. 1, if device n𝑛n was not selected in round t−1𝑡1t-1, i.e., Sn(t−1)=0superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡10S_{n}^{(t-1)}=0, or it is not assigned to any sub-channel, i.e., ∑k=1Kψk,n(t−1)=0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡10\sum_{k=1}^{K}\psi_{k,n}^{(t-1)}=0, its information age increments 111; otherwise, its information age is reset to 111.

With this consideration, a large information age implies more informative update, and therefore the device selection should partially depend on the information age. In any round t𝑡t, αn(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡\alpha_{n}^{(t)} defined below is used as a weight to prioritize selecting devices with larger AoI for aggregation:

αn(t)=An(t)∑n′=1NAn′(t).superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐴superscript𝑛′𝑡\alpha_{n}^{(t)}=\frac{A_{n}^{(t)}}{\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}A_{n^{\prime}}^{(t)}}. (7)

II-D Sub-Channel Assignment

According to [6, 22, 12], the convergence rate of FL also depends on the latency of each round. By including computation and communication phases, the time consumption of any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k can be expressed as follows111Note that the time consumption for global model transmission from the server to devices is ignored as in [23, 24].:

Tk,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)=Tk,ncp​(τk,n)+Tk,ncm​(Pk,n).subscript𝑇𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cpsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cmsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛T_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n})=T_{k,n}^{\text{cp}}(\tau_{k,n})+T_{k,n}^{\text{cm}}(P_{k,n}). (8)

For device n𝑛n selected in round t𝑡t, i.e., Sn(t)=1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡1S_{n}^{(t)}=1, a sub-channel is available for transmitting its local model. For the entire FL network, the latency of the t𝑡t-th aggregation round is decided by the maximum time consumption, as shown in follows:

T(t)=maxn∈𝒩t⁡{∑k∈𝒦ψk,n(t)​Tk,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)}.superscript𝑇𝑡subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡subscript𝑇𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛T^{(t)}=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}\left\{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}T_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n})\right\}. (9)

If any device is assigned to a sub-channel with the enhanced channel gain, the time consumption of this device decreases, and hence, the latency of this round may be reduced. Moveover, the energy consumption of any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k is given by

Ek,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)=Ek,ncp​(τk,n)+Ek,ncm​(Pk,n).subscript𝐸𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cpsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cmsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛E_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n})=E_{k,n}^{\text{cp}}(\tau_{k,n})+E_{k,n}^{\text{cm}}(P_{k,n}). (10)

III Problem Formulation

In order to improve the performance of FL in the considered scenario, this paper chooses the convergence time as the target, which is jointly determined by the number of rounds and the time consumption of each round [6]. Therefore, global loss minimization and latency minimization should be jointly considered. This situation can be described as a Stackelberg game, where global loss minimization and latency minimization are considered as leader-level and follower-level problems, respectively.

III-1 Leader-Level Problem (Computation)

In the considered FL algorithm, the local loss at any device n𝑛n is given by

Fn​(𝒈)=1βn​∑i=1βnℓ​(𝒈;𝒙n,i,yn,i),subscript𝐹𝑛𝒈1subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛ℓ𝒈subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖F_{n}(\boldsymbol{g})=\frac{1}{\beta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\ell(\boldsymbol{g};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}), (11)

where ℓ​(𝒘;𝒙n,i,yn,i)ℓ𝒘subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖\ell(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}) is a loss function, 𝒙n,isubscript𝒙𝑛𝑖\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i} is the i𝑖i-th input data of device n𝑛n, and yn,isubscript𝑦𝑛𝑖y_{n,i} is the corresponding label. By including device selection and sub-channel assignment, the aggregated global model in round t𝑡t is given by

𝒈(t)=∑n=1NSn(t−1)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t−1)​βn​𝒘n(t−1)∑n=1NSn(t−1)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t−1)​βn.superscript𝒈𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡1subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡1subscript𝛽𝑛\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!S_{n}^{(t-1)}\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}\!\psi_{k,n}^{(t-1)}\!\beta_{n}\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{(t-1)}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}S_{n}^{(t-1)}\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}\!\psi_{k,n}^{(t-1)}\beta_{n}}. (12)

At the computation phase, in order to minimize the global loss, an AoI based device selection problem can be formulated as follows:

min𝐒subscript𝐒\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{S}}\quad ∑n=1Nαn(t)​Sn(t)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t)​∑i=1βnℓ​(𝒈(t);𝒙n,i,yn,i)∑n=1Nαn(t)​Sn(t)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t)​βn,superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛ℓsuperscript𝒈𝑡subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!\alpha_{n}^{(t)}S_{n}^{(t)}\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}\!\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\!\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\!\ell(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!\alpha_{n}^{(t)}S_{n}^{(t)}\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}\!\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\beta_{n}},\! (13)
s.t. Sn(t)∈{0,1},∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡01for-all𝑛𝒩\displaystyle S_{n}^{(t)}\in\{0,1\},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, (13a)
∑n=1NSn(t)≤K,.superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡𝐾\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{n=1}^{N}S_{n}^{(t)}\leq K,. (13b)

Constraints (13a) and (13b) indicate that all devices are available for selection, and the number of selected devices in each round is not greater than the number of available sub-channels.

III-2 Follower-Level Problem (Communication)

Based on the given 𝐒𝐒\mathbf{S}, the set of selected devices 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t} can be obtained. Hence, sub-channel assignment, computational resource allocation, and power allocation are implemented in order to minimize the latency. In any round t𝑡t, the latency minimization problem can be presented as follows:

min𝝍,𝝉,𝐏subscript𝝍𝝉𝐏\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\psi},\boldsymbol{\tau},\mathbf{P}}\quad maxn∈𝒩t⁡{∑k∈𝒦ψk,n(t)​Tk,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)},subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡subscript𝑇𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}\left\{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}T_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n})\right\}, (14)
s.t. Ek,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)≤Enmax,subscript𝐸𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max\displaystyle E_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n})\leq E_{n}^{\text{max}}, (14a)
Tk,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)≤Tmax,subscript𝑇𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscript𝑇max\displaystyle T_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n})\leq T^{\text{max}}, (14b)
τk,n∈[0,1],Pk,n∈[0,Pnmax],formulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛01subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛max\displaystyle\tau_{k,n}\in[0,1],P_{k,n}\in[0,P_{n}^{\text{max}}], (14c)
∑n∈𝒩tψk,n(t)∈{0,1},ψk,n(t)∈{0,1},formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡01superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡01\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\in\{0,1\},\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\in\{0,1\}, (14d)
∑k∈𝒦ψk,n(t)∈{0,1},ψk,n(t)∈{0,1},,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡01superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡01\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\in\{0,1\},\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\in\{0,1\},, (14e)

where 𝝍𝝍\boldsymbol{\psi}, 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}, and 𝝉𝝉\boldsymbol{\tau} are the collections of sub-channel assignment indicators, transmit power, and computational resource allocation coefficients, respectively. In constraints (14a) and (14b), the energy limitation Enmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛maxE_{n}^{\text{max}} and the maximum tolerance time Tmaxsuperscript𝑇maxT^{\text{max}} are included, respectively. In constraint (14c), the value ranges of computational resource allocation coefficients and transmit power are presented, respectively. Constraints (14d) and (14e) respectively indicate that each sub-channel can be occupied by maximum one device, and each device can be assigned to maximum one sub-channel. Note that any device or sub-channel is not assigned only if constraints (14a) and (14b) cannot be satisfied by the corresponding assignment.

III-3 Stackelberg Equilibrium

In a Stackelberg game, the leader can predict the strategy of the follower, and then propose its strategy first. For the follower, it can observe the strategy of the leader and provide its response. Specifically, in the formulated Stackelberg game based problem, the leader selects devices for minimizing global loss, and then the follower assigns sub-channels to the selected devices and adjusts computational resource allocation coefficients and transmit power for minimizing latency. By predicting the best response of the follower, the leader can obtain the feasibility of the selected devices in the considered system, and provide the corresponding optimal device selection strategy. This solution follows Stackelberg equilibrium [25, 26], as shown below.

Definition 1.

In the formulated Stackelberg game based problem, by respectively defining Gleadersubscript𝐺leaderG_{\text{leader}} and Gfollowersubscript𝐺followerG_{\text{follower}} as the objective functions of leader-level and follower-level problems, solution (𝐒∗,𝛙∗,𝛕∗,𝐏∗)superscript𝐒superscript𝛙superscript𝛕superscript𝐏(\mathbf{S}^{*},\boldsymbol{\psi}^{*},\boldsymbol{\tau}^{*},\mathbf{P}^{*}) is the Stackelberg equilibrium if the following conditions hold:

Gleader​(𝐒∗,𝝍∗,𝝉∗,𝐏∗)≤Gleader​(𝐒,𝝍∗,𝝉∗,𝐏∗),Gfollower​(𝐒∗,𝝍∗,𝝉∗,𝐏∗)≤Gfollower​(𝐒∗,𝝍,𝝉,𝐏).subscript𝐺leadersuperscript𝐒superscript𝝍superscript𝝉superscript𝐏absentsubscript𝐺leader𝐒superscript𝝍superscript𝝉superscript𝐏subscript𝐺followersuperscript𝐒superscript𝝍superscript𝝉superscript𝐏absentsubscript𝐺followersuperscript𝐒𝝍𝝉𝐏\begin{array}[]{ll}G_{\text{leader}}(\mathbf{S}^{*},\boldsymbol{\psi}^{*},\boldsymbol{\tau}^{*},\mathbf{P}^{*})&\!\!\!\leq G_{\text{leader}}(\mathbf{S},\boldsymbol{\psi}^{*},\boldsymbol{\tau}^{*},\mathbf{P}^{*}),\\ G_{\text{follower}}(\mathbf{S}^{*},\boldsymbol{\psi}^{*},\boldsymbol{\tau}^{*},\mathbf{P}^{*})&\!\!\!\leq G_{\text{follower}}(\mathbf{S}^{*},\boldsymbol{\psi},\boldsymbol{\tau},\mathbf{P}).\end{array} (15)

In order to achieve Stackelberg equilibrium, the best response of the follower should be obtained, and then the leader can propose its strategy with all possible responses. That is, for any solution of the leader-level problem, i.e., 𝐒𝐒\mathbf{S}, the optimal solution of the follower-level problem, i.e., 𝝍∗superscript𝝍\boldsymbol{\psi}^{*}, 𝝉∗superscript𝝉\boldsymbol{\tau}^{*}, and 𝐏∗superscript𝐏\mathbf{P}^{*}, is obtained. Afterwards, the optimal solution of the leader-level problem, i.e., 𝐒∗superscript𝐒\mathbf{S}^{*}, is obtained with 𝝍∗superscript𝝍\boldsymbol{\psi}^{*}, 𝝉∗superscript𝝉\boldsymbol{\tau}^{*}, and 𝐏∗superscript𝐏\mathbf{P}^{*}.

IV Solution of Follower-Level Problem

The formulated follower-level problem in (14) is a non-convex problem with binary constraints. In this section, the follower-level problem is decoupled into two sub-problems and solved iteratively. With fixed sub-channel assignment, the sub-problem related to computational resource allocation and power allocation can be presented as follows:

𝚪=min𝝉,𝐏𝚪subscript𝝉𝐏\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\Gamma}=\min_{\boldsymbol{\tau},\mathbf{P}}\quad {Tk,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)|∀n∈𝒩t,∀k∈𝒦},conditional-setsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛formulae-sequencefor-all𝑛subscript𝒩𝑡for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\left\{T_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n})|\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{t},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}\right\}, (16)
s.t. (14a), (14c),(14a), (14c)\displaystyle\text{(\ref{fproblem}a), (\ref{fproblem}c)},

where 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma} is a K×|𝒩t|𝐾subscript𝒩𝑡K\times|\mathcal{N}_{t}| matrix containing the minimum time consumptions for all possible device and sub-channel combinations. With the given matrix 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma}, the sub-problem related to sub-channel assignment can be presented as follows:

min𝝍subscript𝝍\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\psi}}\quad maxn∈𝒩t⁡{∑k∈𝒦ψk,n(t)​Γk,n},subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡subscriptΓ𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}\left\{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\Gamma_{k,n}\right\}, (17)
s.t. (14b), (14d), (14e),(14b), (14d), (14e)\displaystyle\text{(\ref{fproblem}b), (\ref{fproblem}d), (\ref{fproblem}e)},

where Γk,nsubscriptΓ𝑘𝑛\Gamma_{k,n} is one element of matrix 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma}. Note that the time consumption constraint (14b) is included in problem (17), and hence, all combinations of device and sub-channels are feasible for problem (16). Moreover, since matrix 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma} is the minimum time consumptions of all possible combinations, if constraint (14b) is still not satisfied in problem (17), the corresponding combination cannot be adopted in sub-channel assignment.

IV-A Joint Optimization of Power Allocation and Computational Resource Allocation

In this subsection, power allocation and computational resource allocation are jointly optimized with the fixed device selection and sub-channel assignment. It is indicated in problem (16) that the time consumption of any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k only depends on its own computational resource allocation coefficient τk,nsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n} and transmit power Pk,nsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛P_{k,n}. Therefore, in order to generate matrix 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma}, problem (16) can be divided into multiple sub-problems, where each sub-problem corresponds to one device and sub-channel combination. For any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k, the sub-problem is given by

minτk,n,Pk,nsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\min_{\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n}}\!\quad\! μ​βnτk,n​Cn+D​(𝒘n)B​log2⁡(1+Pk,n​|hk,n|2)𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛𝐷subscript𝒘𝑛𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle\frac{\mu\beta_{n}}{\tau_{k,n}C_{n}}+\frac{D(\boldsymbol{w}_{n})}{B\log_{2}(1+P_{k,n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})} (18)
s.t. κ0​μ​βn​(τk,n​Cn)2+Pk,n​D​(𝒘n)B​log2⁡(1+Pk,n​|hk,n|2)≤Enmax,subscript𝜅0𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛2subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛𝐷subscript𝒘𝑛𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max\displaystyle\kappa_{0}\mu\beta_{n}(\tau_{k,n}C_{n})^{2}\!\!+\!\!\frac{P_{k,n}D(\boldsymbol{w}_{n})}{B\log_{2}(1\!\!+\!\!P_{k,n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})}\!\leq\!E_{n}^{\text{max}}, (18a)
τk,n∈[0,1],Pk,n∈[0,Pnmax].formulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛01subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛max\displaystyle\tau_{k,n}\in[0,1],P_{k,n}\in[0,P_{n}^{\text{max}}]. (18b)

Due to the fact that problem (18) is still non-convex, the traditional optimization methods, such as convex optimization, cannot be directly employed. Therefore, monotonic optimization is introduced to solve this problem. In order to utilize monotonic optimization, the monotonicity of problem (18) should be analyzed. According to [27], the following proposition can be obtained.

Proposition 1.

For any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k, with computational resource allocation coefficient τk,nsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n} and transmit power Pk,nsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛P_{k,n}, the time consumption Tk,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)subscript𝑇𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛T_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n}) is a decreasing function, while the energy consumption Ek,n​(τk,n,Pk,n)subscript𝐸𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛E_{k,n}(\tau_{k,n},P_{k,n}) is an increasing function.

Proof:

Refer to Appendix A. ∎

According to Proposition 1, it can be proved that the objective function and all constraints in problem (18) are monotonic. Next, this problem should be transformed to a canonical formulation for solving. By defining the power allocation coefficient pk,n∈[0,1]subscript𝑝𝑘𝑛01p_{k,n}\in[0,1], the objective function in problem (18) is equivalent to maximizing the following function:

where 𝐳k,n∈ℝ+2×1subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscriptℝ21\mathbf{z}_{k,n}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2\times 1} is the collection of the power allocation coefficient and computational resource allocation coefficient, i.e., 𝐳k,n={τk,n,pk,n}subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘𝑛\mathbf{z}_{k,n}=\{\tau_{k,n},p_{k,n}\}. g​(𝐳k,n)𝑔subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛\displaystyle g(\mathbf{z}_{k,n}) (20)
=\displaystyle= κ0​μ​βn​(τk,n​Cn)2+pk,n​Pnmax​D​(𝒘n)B​log2⁡(1+pk,n​Pnmax​|hk,n|2)−Enmax.subscript𝜅0𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛2subscript𝑝𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛max𝐷subscript𝒘𝑛𝐵subscript21subscript𝑝𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛maxsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max\displaystyle\kappa_{0}\mu\beta_{n}(\tau_{k,n}C_{n})^{2}\!+\!\frac{p_{k,n}P_{n}^{\text{max}}D(\boldsymbol{w}_{n})}{B\log_{2}(1\!+\!p_{k,n}P_{n}^{\text{max}}|h_{k,n}|^{2})}\!-\!E_{n}^{\text{max}}.

max𝐳k,nsubscriptsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\max_{\mathbf{z}_{k,n}}\quad f​(𝐳k,n)𝑓subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛\displaystyle f(\mathbf{z}_{k,n}) (21)
s.t. g​(𝐳k,n)≤0,𝑔subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛0\displaystyle g(\mathbf{z}_{k,n})\leq 0, (21a)

Based on the value range of the computational resource allocation coefficient and power allocation coefficient, a normal set 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} can be defined as follows:

𝒢={𝐳k,n∈[𝟎,𝟏]|g​(𝐳k,n)≤0}.𝒢conditional-setsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑛01𝑔subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛0\mathcal{G}=\{\mathbf{z}_{k,n}\in[\mathbf{0},\mathbf{1}]|g(\mathbf{z}_{k,n})\leq 0\}. (22)

As a result, problem (18) can be presented in a canonical formulation of monotonic optimization, as shown in follows:

max𝐳k,nsubscriptsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\max_{\mathbf{z}_{k,n}}\quad f​(𝐳k,n)𝑓subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛\displaystyle f(\mathbf{z}_{k,n}) (23)
s.t. 𝐳k,n∈𝒢.subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛𝒢\displaystyle\mathbf{z}_{k,n}\in\mathcal{G}. (23a)

In problem (23), the objective function f​(𝐳k,n)𝑓subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛f(\mathbf{z}_{k,n}) is monotonically increasing with 𝐳k,nsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑛\mathbf{z}_{k,n}, and then the optimal solution is located on the boundary of the feasible set 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. However, due to the non-convexity of functions f​(𝐳k,n)𝑓subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛f(\mathbf{z}_{k,n}) and g​(𝐳k,n)𝑔subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛g(\mathbf{z}_{k,n}), the expression of the boundary cannot be directly derived. In this case, the polyblock outer approximation algorithm in [28] is adopted, which can approach the feasible set 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} by constructing polyblock 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. The polyblock outer approximation algorithm is presented in Algorithm 1.

As shown in Fig. 2(a), by setting the first vertex 𝐯(1)∈𝒱(1)superscript𝐯1superscript𝒱1\mathbf{v}^{(1)}\in\mathcal{V}^{(1)}, the initial polyblock 𝒫(1)superscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}^{(1)} can be constructed as the box [𝟎,𝟏]01[\mathbf{0},\mathbf{1}], which contains the feasible set222Note that the initial vertex, i.e., τk,n=1subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛1\tau_{k,n}=1 and pk,n=1subscript𝑝𝑘𝑛1p_{k,n}=1, may be infeasible for problem (23). However, the optimal solution obtained from Algorithm 1 is the projection of the vertex, which is always included in the feasible set 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}.. The projection of 𝐯(1)superscript𝐯1\mathbf{v}^{(1)} on the upper boundary of feasible set 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is calculated, denoted by ϕ​(𝐯(1))bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯1\boldsymbol{\phi}(\mathbf{v}^{(1)}). where vi(1)superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖1v_{i}^{(1)} is the i𝑖i-th element of 𝐯(1)superscript𝐯1\mathbf{v}^{(1)}, ϕi​(𝐯(1))subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖superscript𝐯1\phi_{i}(\mathbf{v}^{(1)}) is the i𝑖i-th element of ϕ​(𝐯(1))bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯1\boldsymbol{\phi}(\mathbf{v}^{(1)}), and 𝐞isubscript𝐞𝑖\mathbf{e}_{i} is the i𝑖i-th unit vector. 𝒱(2)={𝒱(1)\𝐯(1)}∪{𝐯~1(1),𝐯~2(1)}.superscript𝒱2\superscript𝒱1superscript𝐯1superscriptsubscript~𝐯11superscriptsubscript~𝐯21\mathcal{V}^{(2)}=\{\mathcal{V}^{(1)}\backslash\mathbf{v}^{(1)}\}\cup\{\mathbf{\tilde{v}}_{1}^{(1)},\mathbf{\tilde{v}}_{2}^{(1)}\}. (25)

After that, the optimal vertex is selected from vertex set 𝒱(2)superscript𝒱2\mathcal{V}^{(2)} and denoted by 𝐯(2)superscript𝐯2\mathbf{v}^{(2)}, which satisfies the following condition:

𝐯(2)=argmax{f​(ϕ​(𝐯))|𝐯∈𝒱(2)}.superscript𝐯2argmaxconditional𝑓bold-italic-ϕ𝐯𝐯superscript𝒱2\mathbf{v}^{(2)}=\operatorname*{argmax}\{f(\boldsymbol{\phi}(\mathbf{v}))|\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{V}^{(2)}\}. (26)

That is, the projection of the optimal vertex can achieve the maximum value of the objective function, i.e., (19). For example, Fig. 2(c) shows the case that 𝐯~1(1)superscriptsubscript~𝐯11\mathbf{\tilde{v}}_{1}^{(1)} is selected as the optimal vertex 𝐯(2)superscript𝐯2\mathbf{v}^{(2)}. This algorithm is completed if the following condition is satisfied:

|f​(ϕ​(𝐯(θ)))−f​(ϕ​(𝐯(θ−1)))|≤ϵ,𝑓bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯𝜃𝑓bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯𝜃1italic-ϵ|f(\boldsymbol{\phi}(\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)}))-f(\boldsymbol{\phi}(\mathbf{v}^{(\theta-1)}))|\leq\epsilon, (27)

where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the error tolerance. The output 𝐳k,n∗=ϕ​(𝐯(θ))superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑛bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯𝜃\mathbf{z}_{k,n}^{*}=\boldsymbol{\phi}(\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)}) is the optimal solution of problem (23).

The projection of any vertex 𝐯(θ)superscript𝐯𝜃\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)} satisfies the following condition:

ϕ​(𝐯(θ))=ζ​𝐯(θ),bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯𝜃𝜁superscript𝐯𝜃\boldsymbol{\phi}(\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)})=\zeta\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)}, (28)

where ζ∈(0,1)𝜁01\zeta\in(0,1) is a ratio coefficient obtained as follows:

ζ𝜁\displaystyle\zeta =max⁡{ζ~∈(0,1)|ζ~​𝐯(θ)∈𝒢}absent~𝜁conditional01~𝜁superscript𝐯𝜃𝒢\displaystyle=\max\{\tilde{\zeta}\in(0,1)|\tilde{\zeta}\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)}\in\mathcal{G}\}
=max⁡{ζ~∈(0,1)|g​(ζ~​𝐯(θ))≤0,ζ~​𝐯(θ)∈[𝟎,𝟏]}.absent~𝜁conditional01𝑔~𝜁superscript𝐯𝜃0~𝜁superscript𝐯𝜃01\displaystyle=\max\{\tilde{\zeta}\in(0,1)|g(\tilde{\zeta}\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)})\leq 0,\tilde{\zeta}\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)}\in[\mathbf{0},\mathbf{1}]\}. (29)

Since that g​(ζ~​𝐯(θ))𝑔~𝜁superscript𝐯𝜃g(\tilde{\zeta}\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)}) is a monotonic increasing function, ζ𝜁\zeta satisfies g​(ζ​𝐯(θ))=0𝑔𝜁superscript𝐯𝜃0g(\zeta\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)})=0, which can be written as follows:

κ0​μ​βn​(ζ​v1(θ)​Cn)2+ζ​v2(θ)​Pnmax​D​(𝒘n)B​log2⁡(1+ζ​v2(θ)​Pnmax​|hk,n|2)=Enmax.subscript𝜅0𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscript𝜁superscriptsubscript𝑣1𝜃subscript𝐶𝑛2𝜁superscriptsubscript𝑣2𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛max𝐷subscript𝒘𝑛𝐵subscript21𝜁superscriptsubscript𝑣2𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛maxsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max\kappa_{0}\mu\beta_{n}(\zeta v_{1}^{(\theta)}C_{n})^{2}\!+\!\frac{\zeta v_{2}^{(\theta)}P_{n}^{\text{max}}D(\boldsymbol{w}_{n})}{B\log_{2}(1\!+\!\zeta v_{2}^{(\theta)}P_{n}^{\text{max}}|h_{k,n}|^{2})}=E_{n}^{\text{max}}. (30)

The closed-form expression of ζ𝜁\zeta cannot be presented, but this nonlinear equation can be solved by multiple numerical solvers, such as MATLAB. It is worth pointing out that during Algorithm 1, with any given vertex 𝐯(θ)={v1(θ),v2(θ)}superscript𝐯𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑣1𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑣2𝜃\mathbf{v}^{(\theta)}=\{v_{1}^{(\theta)},v_{2}^{(\theta)}\}, where θ≥2𝜃2\theta\geq 2, condition ζ∈(0,1)𝜁01\zeta\in(0,1) is always satisfied. When θ=1𝜃1\theta=1, ζ=1𝜁1\zeta=1 may be obtained with vertex 𝐯(1)={v1(1),v2(θ)}superscript𝐯1superscriptsubscript𝑣11superscriptsubscript𝑣2𝜃\mathbf{v}^{(1)}=\{v_{1}^{(1)},v_{2}^{(\theta)}\}, which means the feasible set 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} includes the first vertex. That is, the energy consumption constraint g​(𝐳k,n)<0𝑔subscript𝐳𝑘𝑛0g(\mathbf{z}_{k,n})<0 can be satisfied with any τk,nsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n} and pk,nsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑛p_{k,n} in [0,1]01[0,1]. In this case, the optimal solution is obtained by 𝐳k,n∗=𝐯(1)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑛superscript𝐯1\mathbf{z}_{k,n}^{*}=\mathbf{v}^{(1)}.

IV-B Matching based Sub-Channel Assignment

Based on Algorithm 1, the minimum time consumptions of all selected devices in all sub-channels is obtained in matrix 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma}. In this subsection, a matching based algorithm is proposed to solve the binary integer programming problem in (17), where matrix 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma} is utilized to construct the preference list.

In the sub-channel assignment problem, the set of selected devices, i.e., 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t}, is available. Moreover, as revealed in Section V, in order to maximize the weighted global loss, the number of selected devices should be maximized in each round, i.e., |𝒩t|=Ksubscript𝒩𝑡𝐾|\mathcal{N}_{t}|=K. In this case, 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t} and 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} are two disjoint sets with the same size, and hence, this scenario can be considered as a one-to-one matching ΨΨ\Psi from 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t} to 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}. Based on matrix 𝚪𝚪\boldsymbol{\Gamma}, in any matching ΨΨ\Psi, the utility of device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k can be presented as follows:

Un​(Ψ)={Umax,if Γk,n>Tmax,Γk,n,otherwise,subscript𝑈𝑛Ψcasessubscript𝑈maxif Γk,n>TmaxsubscriptΓ𝑘𝑛otherwiseU_{n}(\Psi)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}U_{\text{max}},&\text{if $\Gamma_{k,n}>T^{\text{max}}$},\\ \Gamma_{k,n},&\text{otherwise},\end{array}\right. (31)

where Umaxsubscript𝑈maxU_{\text{max}} is a large constant indicating that the assignment of device n𝑛n and sub-channel k𝑘k is infeasible. In the matching phase, all devices and sub-channels are matched, and hence, the utility of any sub-channel is equal to the utility of the occupied device, i.e., Uk​(Ψ)=UΨ​(k)​(Ψ),∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝑈𝑘Ψsubscript𝑈Ψ𝑘Ψfor-all𝑘𝒦U_{k}(\Psi)=U_{\Psi(k)}(\Psi),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. By calculating the utility, the preference list of any player can be established. Due to the fact that the formulated sub-channel assignment problem is a latency minimization problem, the preference of any device n𝑛n is defined as follows:

(k,Ψ)≺n(k′,Ψ′)⇒Un​(Ψ)>Un​(Ψ′).subscriptprecedes𝑛𝑘Ψsuperscript𝑘′superscriptΨ′⇒subscript𝑈𝑛Ψsubscript𝑈𝑛superscriptΨ′(k,\Psi)\prec_{n}(k^{\prime},\Psi^{\prime})\Rightarrow U_{n}(\Psi)>U_{n}(\Psi^{\prime}). (32)

The above function indicates that device n𝑛n is willing to be assigned to sub-channel k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} in matching Ψ′superscriptΨ′\Psi^{\prime}, rather than k𝑘k in matching ΨΨ\Psi, since its utility can be strictly decreased by assigning from k𝑘k to k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime}. Similarly, the preference of any sub-channel k𝑘k can be defined as follows:

(n,Ψ)≺k(n′,Ψ′)⇒Uk​(Ψ)>Uk​(Ψ′).subscriptprecedes𝑘𝑛Ψsuperscript𝑛′superscriptΨ′⇒subscript𝑈𝑘Ψsubscript𝑈𝑘superscriptΨ′(n,\Psi)\prec_{k}(n^{\prime},\Psi^{\prime})\Rightarrow U_{k}(\Psi)>U_{k}(\Psi^{\prime}). (33)

Since all players are matched, the considered case follows the concept of two-sided exchange matchings [29]. Therefore, when any device intends to be assigned to a sub-channel, it needs to exchange with another device occupying this sub-channel, instead of directly joining this sub-channel. A notation Ψn′nsuperscriptsubscriptΨsuperscript𝑛′𝑛\Psi_{n^{\prime}}^{n} is introduced to represent the case where exactly two devices n𝑛n and n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} are swapped in any matching ΨΨ\Psi, which is defined as follows:

Ψn′n​(l)={Ψ​(l),l≠n,n′Ψ​(n′)=k′,l=nΨ​(n)=k,l=n′superscriptsubscriptΨsuperscript𝑛′𝑛𝑙casesΨ𝑙𝑙𝑛superscript𝑛′Ψsuperscript𝑛′superscript𝑘′𝑙𝑛Ψ𝑛𝑘𝑙superscript𝑛′\Psi_{n^{\prime}}^{n}(l)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\Psi(l),&l\not=n,\;n^{\prime}\\ \Psi(n^{\prime})=k^{\prime},&l=n\\ \Psi(n)=k,&l=n^{\prime}\end{array}\right. (34)

where Ψn′nsuperscriptsubscriptΨsuperscript𝑛′𝑛\Psi_{n^{\prime}}^{n} only replaces two pairs defined by Ψ​(n)=kΨ𝑛𝑘\Psi(n)=k and Ψ​(n′)=k′Ψsuperscript𝑛′superscript𝑘′\Psi(n^{\prime})=k^{\prime} into Ψ​(n)=k′Ψ𝑛superscript𝑘′\Psi(n)=k^{\prime} and Ψ​(n′)=kΨsuperscript𝑛′𝑘\Psi(n^{\prime})=k, respectively. It is indicated that any swap operation involves four players, and hence, the swap operation should be approved by the involved players. Specifically, at least one player i∈{n,n′,k,k′}𝑖𝑛superscript𝑛′𝑘superscript𝑘′i\in\{n,n^{\prime},k,k^{\prime}\} can reduce its utility without increasing the others’ utilities. In this case, a swap-blocking pair (n,n′)𝑛superscript𝑛′(n,n^{\prime}) is formed, which is defined as follows [30]:

Definition 2.

A swap-blocking pair (n,n′)𝑛superscript𝑛′(n,n^{\prime}) is confirmed if and only if the following conditions hold

  1. 1.

    Ui​(Ψn′n)≤Ui​(Ψ),∀i∈{n,n′,k,k′}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑈𝑖superscriptsubscriptΨsuperscript𝑛′𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖Ψfor-all𝑖𝑛superscript𝑛′𝑘superscript𝑘′U_{i}(\Psi_{n^{\prime}}^{n})\leq U_{i}(\Psi),\forall i\in\{n,n^{\prime},k,k^{\prime}\};

  2. 2.

    At least one inequality above is strict.

By searching swap-blocking pairs, a matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm can be proposed in Algorithm 2. The proposed algorithm can be started from any initial matching. During the algorithm, an active device n𝑛n is selected and try to sequentially swap with all other devices. If a swap-blocking pair (n,n′)𝑛superscript𝑛′(n,n^{\prime}) is formed, i.e., the conditions in Definition 2 are satisfied, the new matching Ψn′nsuperscriptsubscriptΨsuperscript𝑛′𝑛\Psi_{n^{\prime}}^{n} is recorded, and the algorithm continues. The main loop of Algorithm 2 executes repeatedly. When the last device has searched for all other devices, the first device becomes the active device again. The algorithm ends if no swap blocking pair can be found in a full round of the main loop. At this stage, the final matching is outputted as the solution of problem (17). If any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k cannot satisfy constraint (14b), its sub-channel assignment indicator is set to ψk,n=0subscript𝜓𝑘𝑛0\psi_{k,n}=0.

In this subsection, the properties of the proposed matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm, including complexity, convergence, and stability, are analyzed.

IV-B1 Complexity

The computational complexity of the proposed matching based algorithm can be presented by considering the worst case.

Proposition 2.

With the given number of main loops C𝐶C, the computational complexity of the matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm is 𝒪​(C​K2)𝒪𝐶superscript𝐾2\mathcal{O}(CK^{2}).

Proof:

The worst case can be defined as the situation that all devices need to search all other devices. In the main loop, K𝐾K devices can play the role of active devices, and each one searches K−1𝐾1K-1 devices. Hence, K​(K−1)𝐾𝐾1K(K-1) times of calculations should be performed in one loop. With the given number of main loops C𝐶C, the complexity of the proposed algorithm can be expressed as 𝒪​(C​K2)𝒪𝐶superscript𝐾2\mathcal{O}(CK^{2}). ∎

IV-B2 Convergence

The convergence of the proposed sub-channel assignment algorithm is presented as follows.

Proposition 3.

From any initial matching, the matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm is guaranteed to converge to a stable matching.

Proof:

During the proposed algorithm, the matching is transformed as follows:

Ψinitial→Ψ(1)→Ψ(2)→…→Ψfinal.→superscriptΨinitialsuperscriptΨ(1)→superscriptΨ(2)→…→superscriptΨfinal\Psi^{\text{initial}}\to\Psi^{\text{(1)}}\to\Psi^{\text{(2)}}\to\dots\to\Psi^{\text{final}}. (35)

Assume that Ψ(a)superscriptΨ(a)\Psi^{\text{(a)}} and Ψ(b)superscriptΨ(b)\Psi^{\text{(b)}} are two adjacent matching, i.e., Ψ(a)→Ψ(b)→superscriptΨ(a)superscriptΨ(b)\Psi^{\text{(a)}}\to\Psi^{\text{(b)}}, one swap-blocking pair is found among the transformation. According to Definition 2, at least one player can achieve less utility, and the utilities of all players cannot be increased. The following inequality is always satisfied:

∑i∈𝒩tUi​(Ψ(a))>∑i∈𝒩tUi​(Ψ(b)).subscript𝑖subscript𝒩𝑡subscript𝑈𝑖superscriptΨ(a)subscript𝑖subscript𝒩𝑡subscript𝑈𝑖superscriptΨ(b)\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}U_{i}(\Psi^{\text{(a)}})>\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}U_{i}(\Psi^{\text{(b)}}). (36)

Therefore, the matching transformation in (35) cannot be reversed. With the finite number of devices and sub-channels, the number of possible matchings is finite and equal to the Bell number [31]. Therefore, the final matching can be always obtained. ∎

IV-B3 Stability

The stability of the proposed matching based algorithm follows the following definition [29, 30]:

Definition 3.

A matching ΨΨ\Psi is two-sided exchange-stable (2ES) if and only if there is no further swap-blocking pair.

Based on the above definition, the stability of the matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm can be expressed as follows:

Proposition 4.

Any final matching obtained from Algorithm 2 is 2ES.

Proof:

If the final matching obtained from Algorithm 2 is not 2ES, there exists at least one swap-blocking pair, which can further reduce the sum utility of all devices. However, it contradicts the conditions for completing the algorithm. This proposition is proved. ∎

V Solution of Leader-Level Problem

In order to solve the formulated global loss minimization problem in (13), the impact of device selection on the expected convergence rate should be analyzed. By employing the gradient descent method, with the given global model 𝒈(t)superscript𝒈𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}, device n𝑛n can update the local model as follows:

𝒘n(t)=𝒈(t)−λβn​∑i=1βn∇ℓ​(𝒈(t);𝒙n,i,yn,i),superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑡superscript𝒈𝑡𝜆subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛∇ℓsuperscript𝒈𝑡subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{{(t)}}=\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}-\frac{\lambda}{\beta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\nabla\ell(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}), (37)

∇F​(𝒈(t))=∑n=1N∑i=1βn∇ℓ​(𝒈(t);𝒙n,i,yn,i)∑n=1Nβn,∇𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛∇ℓsuperscript𝒈𝑡subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\nabla\ell(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n}}, (39)

To derive the expected convergence rate of FL in any round t𝑡t, based on [7, 32, 8], the following assumptions are considered:

  1. 1.

    With respect to 𝒈𝒈\boldsymbol{g}, the gradient ∇F​(𝒈)∇𝐹𝒈\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}) of F​(𝒈)𝐹𝒈F(\boldsymbol{g}) is uniformly Lipschitz continuous, i.e.,

    ‖∇F​(𝒈(t+1))−∇F​(𝒈(t))‖≤L​‖𝒈(t+1)−𝒈(t)‖,norm∇𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡1∇𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡𝐿normsuperscript𝒈𝑡1superscript𝒈𝑡\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t+1)})-\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})\|\leq L\|\boldsymbol{g}^{(t+1)}-\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\|, (41)

    where L𝐿L is a positive constant, and ∥∙∥\|\bullet\| is the norm operator.

  2. 2.

    The following inequality is satisfied with any device n𝑛n and sample i𝑖i:

    ∥∇ℓ(𝒈(t));𝒙n,i,yn,i)∥2≤ρ∥∇F(𝒈(t))∥2,\|\nabla\ell(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)});\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})\|^{2}\leq\rho\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})\|^{2}, (42)

    where ρ𝜌\rho is a non-negative constant.

It is worth pointing out that the above assumptions are commonly considered in the FL related optimization, and can be satisfied by widely adopted loss functions. Based on these assumptions, the following proposition can be derived.

Proposition 5.

In the case that device selection and sub-channel assignment satisfy Sn(t)=∑k=1Kψk,n(t),∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡for-all𝑛𝒩S_{n}^{(t)}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, with the learning rate λ=1/L𝜆1𝐿\lambda=1/L and the optimal global model 𝐠∗superscript𝐠\boldsymbol{g}^{*}, the upper bound of 𝔼​[F​(𝐠(t+1))−F​(𝐠∗)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐠𝑡1𝐹superscript𝐠\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t+1)})-F(\boldsymbol{g}^{*})] in round t𝑡t can be presented as follows:

𝔼​[F​(𝒈(t+1))−F​(𝒈∗)]≤𝔼​[F​(𝒈(t))−F​(𝒈∗)]−12​L​‖∇F​(𝒈(t))‖2𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡1𝐹superscript𝒈𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡𝐹superscript𝒈12𝐿superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡2\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t+1)})\!-\!F(\boldsymbol{g}^{*})]\!\leq\!\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})\!-\!F(\boldsymbol{g}^{*})]\!-\!\frac{1}{2L}\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})\|^{2}
+2​ρ​‖∇F​(𝒈(t))‖2L​∑n=1Nβn​∑n=1Nβn​(1−Sn(t)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t)).2𝜌superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡2𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\quad\quad\quad\quad+\!\frac{2\rho\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})\|^{2}}{L\!\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!\beta_{n}}\!\!\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!\beta_{n}\!\!\left(\!1\!-\!S_{n}^{(t)}\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}\!\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\!\right).\!\! (43)
Proof:

Refer to Appendix B. ∎

It is indicated that the convergence rate in any round t𝑡t is bounded by three terms. The first term, i.e., 𝔼​[F​(𝒈(t))−F​(𝒈∗)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡𝐹superscript𝒈\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})-F(\boldsymbol{g}^{*})], is the expected upper bound in the previous round. The second term is the norm of the global model gradient from the previous round. The third term is related to device selection, where the status of devices in round t𝑡t, i.e., Sn(t)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡S_{n}^{(t)}, is included. Proposition 5 indicates the expected gap between the global loss in round t𝑡t and the optimal loss. In this case, the train loss minimization problem in (13) can be achieved by minimizing the expected gap. Moreover, since that the first two terms do not include device selection, they can be treated as constants. Meanwhile, the term 2​ρ​‖∇F​(𝒈(t))‖2L​∑n=1Nαn(t)​βn2𝜌superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒈𝑡2𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛\frac{2\rho\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)})\|^{2}}{L\sum_{n=1}^{N}\alpha_{n}^{(t)}\beta_{n}} is positive and not effected by device selection, and hence, it can be removed. By including the AoI based weight αn(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡\alpha_{n}^{(t)}, the objective function of the leader-level problem (13) can be reformulated as follows:

min𝐒​∑n=1Nβn​(1−αn(t)​Sn(t)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t))subscript𝐒superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡\min_{\mathbf{S}}\!\quad\!\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n}\!\!\left(\!1\!-\!\alpha_{n}^{(t)}S_{n}^{(t)}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)}\!\right) (44)

By removing the constant term ∑n=1Nβnsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n}, the leader-level problem (13) can be equivalently transformed as follows:

max𝐒subscript𝐒\displaystyle\max_{\mathbf{S}}\quad ∑n=1Nαn(t)​βn​Sn(t)​∑k=1Kψk,n(t)superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}\alpha_{n}^{(t)}\beta_{n}S_{n}^{(t)}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\psi_{k,n}^{(t)} (45)
s.t. (13a), (13b).(13a), (13b)\displaystyle\text{(\ref{lproblem}a), (\ref{lproblem}b)}.

The above problem can be treated as a weighted device selection problem, where both AoI and data size play the role of weight factors. For example, the weight of device n𝑛n can be expressed by αn(t)​βnsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛\alpha_{n}^{(t)}\beta_{n}. Therefore, the server can order and select devices based on the priority. In any round t𝑡t, all devices can be sorted and recorded in a list 𝒬(t)superscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}^{(t)}, which satisfies the following condition:

α(1)(t)​β(1)≥α(2)(t)​β(2)≥⋯≥α(N)(t)​β(N),superscriptsubscript𝛼1𝑡subscript𝛽1superscriptsubscript𝛼2𝑡subscript𝛽2⋯superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑁𝑡subscript𝛽𝑁\alpha_{(1)}^{(t)}\beta_{(1)}\geq\alpha_{(2)}^{(t)}\beta_{(2)}\geq\dots\geq\alpha_{(N)}^{(t)}\beta_{(N)}, (46)

where (1)1(1) and (N)𝑁(N) denote the devices with the highest and lowest priority, respectively. On the other hand, for maximizing the utility, the server tends to select more devices, and hence, constraint (13b) can be rewritten as ∑n=1NSn(t)=Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑡𝐾\sum_{n=1}^{N}S_{n}^{(t)}=K. That is, the number of selected devices is equal to the number of available sub-channels. According to the list 𝒬(t)superscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}^{(t)}, problem (45) can be solved by Algorithm 3. In the proposed device selection algorithm, K𝐾K devices with the highest priority are selected in the initialization phase. During Algorithm 3, any device not assigned to a sub-channel will be replaced, until all selected devices have been assigned to sub-channels, or all devices in list 𝒬(t)superscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}^{(t)} have been adopted.

VI Simulation Results

In this section, the performance of the proposed solution is simulated and demonstrated. Multiple device selection (DS) schemes are considered as benchmarks, as shown in follows:

  • •

    With AoI based DS, the server selects devices based on the list in (46).

  • •

    With random DS, the server selects devices randomly.

  • •

    With fixed DS, the same devices are selected in all rounds.

Note that in above schemes, the proposed resource allocation algorithm in Algorithm 1 is adopted. The selected devices can participate in the aggregation of this round only if the time and energy limitations are satisfied. Moreover, the random sub-channel assignment (SA) scheme directly exploits the initial matching in Algorithm 2. The parameters of the simulation are shown in Table I.

Fig. 3 presents the global loss and the corresponding test accuracy of different schemes, where the probability of device selection is shown in Table II. The complete DS scheme is included to show the upper bound, where all devices are selected for the aggregation. It can be found that with the limited number of sub-channels, the proposed solution can achieve the best performance, including the lowest global loss, the fastest convergence rate, and the highest test accuracy. Suppose that the target test accuracy is 94%percent9494\%, the required number of communication rounds for the proposed solution and random DS with matching based SA is 142142142 and 337337337, respectively. The AoI based DS is able to outperform random DS, especially in convergence rate. In the fixed DS, the size of dataset is obviously smaller than other schemes, which leads to the worst performance. By comparing matching based SA and random SA, it can be found the proposed matching based algorithm can improve the performance of FL. This is because the matching based SA can significantly increase the number of selected devices in each communication round, as shown in Table II. It is worth to highlight the proposed device selection algorithm can replace devices, and hence, the number of selected devices is always equal to the number of sub-channels.

In Fig. 4, random resource allocation (RA) is employed to show the performance of the proposed solution, where the time consumption limitation in constraint (14b) is ignored. It is indicated that the proposed RA algorithm and SA algorithm can significantly reduce the time consumption. Based on the proposed solution, the average latency of each communication is 8.92468.92468.9246 s, while the average latency of other schemes is around 363636 s. On the other hand, the proposed matching based SA algorithm can decrease the latency for all DS schemes. The reduction of time consumption with AoI based DS is relatively less than other schemes, since AoI based DS tends to select the devices with large AoI that usually have poor channel conditions.

The improvement of the proposed solution on non-IID data is demonstrated in Fig. 5, where the 111-class non-IID case in [33] is employed. It can be found that compared to other schemes, the proposed solution can still achieve the best performance, and the test accuracy is 3%percent33\% higher than that of random DS. Moreover, AoI based DS can achieve higher test accuracy than random DS within 500500500 communication rounds, which is different from IID data. The performance of fixed DS is obviously worse that that on IID data. This is because only 888 devices can be selected, and then at least 222 digits are missed during training with the NMIST database.

Fig. 6 presents the effect of available sub-channels in the considered FL scenario. With the raising number of available sub-channels, the global loss of all schemes is decreasing, and the corresponding test accuracy is increasing. Compared to other schemes, the proposed solution can achieve the best performance for all sub-channel numbers. It is worth to highlight that the performance of AoI based DS is worse than random DS when the sub-channel number is 222, since the AoI based DS scheme always tries to select devices with poor channel conditions repeatedly. When the number of available sub-channels is greater than or equal to 444, AoI based DS can outperform random DS. The gap between AoI based DS and random DS is reduced with the increasing sub-channel number.

Fig. 7 is an example showing the changes of information age in the proposed solution and the random DS scheme. It can be found that by utilizing the proposed solution, the information age of all devices is relatively small, which means devices are equally selected. In particular, the largest information age is 101010 in the proposed solution. However, in the random DS scheme, the information age of most devices can be 202020, and for the device with poor channel gain, such as device 555, the information age can be 505050. Furthermore, the test accuracy shows that the proposed scheme can achieve nearly 1%percent11\% improvement.

VII Conclusions

This paper investigated FL in a practical wireless communication scenario with limited sub-channels and resources. For minimizing the global loss, the AoI based device selection scheme was proposed to select devices in each communication round, and computational resource allocation, power allocation, and sub-channel assignment were jointly considered to minimize the latency of each round. The monotonicity of the resource allocation problem was analyzed, and then a monotonic optimization based algorithm was developed to find the optimal solution. With the given solution of resource allocation, a matching based algorithm was proposed to solve the sub-channel assignment problem. For the global loss function minimization problem, the upper bound of convergence rate was derived, and AoI was included as part of the weight. By ordering devices according to their priorities, a device selection algorithm was proposed. Simulation results demonstrated that the proposed scheme is able to achieve the near optimal solution, and can significantly improve the test accuracy and latency.

can be obtained. Therefore, (61) can be rewritten as follows:

and the proof is completed.
